subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: keyboard map uploaded
msgSnippet: SNIP On this I disagree more strongly.  In fact, I think it was a great mistake for the Shavian proposal to include the diphthong characters.
messageBody:
SNIP>>>>>>>>>>>>
On this I disagree more strongly.� In fact, I think it
was a great
mistake for the Shavian proposal to include the
diphthong characters.�
This is a conclusion I reached after reading more
about how Unicode
works (see
http://www.unicode.org/sei/ProposalQuestions.html for
a
brief overview on script proposals).� The contextual
forms of the
characters--ligatures included--are not encoded at the
character level.
� And I think it would clearly be a mistake to encode
basic information
with ligatures: it makes it difficult to sort
information.� The Read
Alphabet (I would argue) breaks words down into
discreet phonemes
represented by the junior version of the script: that
is how one would
type in QuickScript (junior or senior), and that is
what should be used
in the Unicode proposal
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

Let me jump in here to strongly second this thought. I
don't know much about Unicode, but there are several
other practical reasons for not shoe-horning
ligatures (or the half-letters!) into any future
computer font for QS.

First, let us remember that QS was created for
fountain pen correspondence by proper ladies and
gentlemen who probably munched watercress sandwiches
while they wrote, and in the days when a single
computer filled a whole office floor. The ligatures
and half-letters, as elegant and gracious as they are
as penmanship, do nothing to improve COMMUNICATION,
which, I venture, is what this project should be all
about. And hunting for them on a keyboard does nothing
to increase writing speed, which is why Read invented
them in the first place.

In truth, including them in a typed font is about as
silly as trying to make our handwriting imitate the
serifed letters carved into Trajan's Monument.

Second, as was said above, our first principle is "one
sound to one letter" and extra characters that are
actually two sounds (and two sounds already
represented by other characters) is bad policy. It
reeks havoc with attempts at frequency statistics
which, after all, should be counting "sounds", not
"characters." With all the recent discussions about
keyboard mapping for QS, it strikes me as foolish to
add more characters to the system, characters which
will take 2 keystrokes to register one glyph, when you
just have to make 2 familiar keystrokes to record the
2 separate sounds of the ligature.

As to the questions raised about QS symbol frequency,
I will be posting a graph soon of my studies.

Cheers!

=====
Bob McBroom Woodstock NY"Begin the morning by saying to yourself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happened to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil. But I have seen the nature of the good, that it is beautiful, and of the bad, that it is ugly, and the nature of him who does wrong, that it is akin to mine, and participates in the same intelligence, and holds the same portion of divinity."- Marcus Aureliius
